columns.text: This exercise requires us to determine the new shares that will be distributed and how the share dividends affect the equity accounts.

**Stock dividend** is a dividend payment to shareholders that is made in shares rather than as cash. It can be classified as small share dividends and large share dividends.

If the shares issued is less than 25% of the total number of shares outstanding, it is considered as **small share dividends**. If the shares issued is 25% or more of the total number of shares outstanding, it is considered as **large share dividends**.

Let's identify the given amounts in the problem.

| | Amounts| 
|--|--:| 
| Common Stock ($0.50 par value)|25,000 | 
| Capital Surplus| 215,000| 
| Retained Earnings|642,700 | 
|Total owner's equity |$882,700 |

## Requirement a

If a company will declare a 10 percent stock dividend, it considered as a **small share dividend**. The amount charged to retained earnings in small share dividends is the total **market value** of share declared as dividends.

To begin, let's first determine the shares outstanding of Vidi International. It is computed by dividing the common stock by the par value.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Share Outstanding} &= \dfrac{\text{Common Stock}}{\text{Par Value}}\\[10pt]
&= \dfrac{\text{\$\hspace{5pt}25,000}}{\text{\$ 0.50}}\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{\text{50,000 shares}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

As can be seen, the number of shares outstanding of the company is 50,000 shares.

Next let's determine the new shares that will be distributed given that the company has a 10 percent stock dividend. It is computed by multiplying the shares outstanding by the percentage of stock dividends,

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{New Shares} &= \text{Shares Outstanding}\times{\text{Percentage of Stock Dividend}}\\[10pt]
&= \text{50,000}\times{\text{10\%}}\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{\textbf{5,000 shares}}\\
\end{aligned}$$


Therefore, **5,000** new shares will be distributed by Vidi International.

Next, let's compute the new common stock by multiplying the sum of shares outstanding and num. of stock dividend by the par value.

$$\begin{aligned} \text{New Common Stock} &= (\text{Share Outstanding}+\text{New Shares}) \times {\text{Par Value}}\\[10pt] &= (\text{50,000}+\text{5,000}) \times {\text{\$ 0.50}}\\[10pt] &= \text{55,000}\times{\text{\$ 0.50}}\\[10pt] &=\boxed{\textbf{\$\hspace{5pt}27,500}}\\ \end{aligned}$$


**As a result, the value of common stock increased from $25,000 to $27,500.**

Next, let's compute the effect on the additional capital surplus. It is computed by multiplying the number of share dividends by the price per share.

$$\begin{aligned} \text{Add'l Capital Surplus} &= \text{New Shares}\times{\text{(Share price - Par Value)}}\\[10pt] 
&= \text{5,000}\times{\text{(\$ 32 - 0.50)}}\\[10pt] 
&= \text{5,000}\times{\text{(\$ 31.50)}}\\[10pt] 
&=\boxed{\$\hspace{5pt}157,500}\\ 
\end{aligned}

Next, we will add the beginning capital surplus and the additional capital surplus to determine the new capital surplus.

$$\begin {array}{lrr} \text{Beginning Capital Suplus}&&\$215,000\\ \text{Add: Add't Capital Surplus}&&\underline{157,500}\\ 
\text{New Capital Surplus}&&\underline{\underline{\$\hspace{5pt}\textbf{372,500}}}\\ \end{array}$$
 

**As a result, the value of capital surplus increased from $215,000 to $372,500.**

In recording the issuance of a stock dividend, the retained earnings will be debited. Hence, we will compute the effect of the stock dividends on the retained earnings.

$$\begin {array}{lrr} \text{Retained Earnings}&&\$ 642,700\\ 
\text{Less: Add'l Capital Stock}&&{\hspace{10pt}2,500}\\ \hspace{24pt}\text{Add'l Capital Surplus}&&\underline{157,500}\\ 
\text{New Retained Earnings}&&\underline{\underline{\textbf{\$\hspace{5pt}482,700}}}\\ \end{array}$$

**As a result, the value of retained earnings decreased from $642,700 to $482,700.**

To summarize the effect of the 10% stock dividends on the equity accounts:


| | Amounts| 
|--|--:| 
| Common Stock ($0.50 par value)|$\text{\$ 27,500}$| 
| Capital Surplus| $\text{372,500}$| 
| Retained Earnings|$\underline{\text{482,700}}$| 
|$\hspace{10pt}\textbf{Total owner's equity}$ |$\underline{\underline{\textbf{\$ 882,700}}}$ |

Small Stock dividends have also no effect on total stockholders' equity or net assets, but they do have an effect on certain equity accounts. It **increases** the value of the company's common stock and capital surplus while **decreasing** the value of its retained earnings.

## Requirement b

If a company will declare a 25 percent stock dividend, it considered as a **large share dividend**. The amount charged to retained earnings in large share dividends is the total **par value** of share declared as dividends.

Now, let's determine the new shares that will be distributed given that the company has a 25 percent stock dividend. 

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{New Shares} &= \text{Shares Outstanding}\times{\text{Percentage of Stock Dividend}}\\[10pt]
&= \text{50,000}\times{\text{25\%}}\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{\textbf{12,500 shares}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, **12,500** new shares will be distributed by Vidi International.

Next, let's compute the new common stock. 

$$\begin{aligned} \text{New Common Stock} &= (\text{Share Outstanding}+\text{New Shares}) \times {\text{Par Value}}\\[10pt] 
&= (\text{50,000}+\text{12,500}) \times {\text{\$ 0.50}}\\[10pt] 
&= \text{62,500}\times{\text{\$ 0.50}}\\[10pt] &=\boxed{\textbf{\$\hspace{5pt}31,250}}\\ 
\end{aligned}$$


**As a result, the value of common stock increased from $25,000 to $31,250.**
Since it is accounted for at par value, **the capital surplus will not be affected** by the declaration of large stock dividends.

Next, we will compute the effect of the stock dividends on the retained earnings.

$$\begin {array}{lrr} \text{Retained Earnings}&&\$ 642,700\\ 
\text{Less: Add'l Capital Stock}&&\underline{\hspace{10pt}6,250}\\ 
\text{New Retained Earnings}&&\underline{\underline{\textbf{\$\hspace{5pt}636,450}}}\\ \end{array}$$

**As a result, the value of retained earnings decreased from $642,700 to $636,450.**

To summarize the effect of the 25% stock dividends on the equity accounts:


| | Amounts| 
|--|--:| 
| Common Stock ($0.50 par value)|$\text{\$ 31,250}$| 
| Capital Surplus| $\text{215,000}$| 
| Retained Earnings|$\underline{\text{636,450}}$| 
|$\hspace{10pt}\textbf{Total owner's equity}$ |$\underline{\underline{\textbf{\$ 882,700}}}$ |

Large Stock dividends have also no effect on total stockholders' equity or net assets, but they do have an effect on certain equity accounts. It **increases** the value of the company's common stock while **decreasing** the value of its retained earnings.
